hero.subtitle: Frontend Designer/ Developer
hero.description: I can help you design and build unique and user-friendly websites your users will love!

about.title: About me
about.bio: Hey there! I'm Audrey, a 28 year old Digital Experience Design student based in Belgium with a big passion for all things creative. Growing up, I spent most of my time drawing, painting, and crafting - heavily inspired by the cartoons I loved. People always told me to do something with my art, but I wasn't sure what that meant. After highschool, I put creativity aside and worked in retail... Until Covid-19 hit. During lockdown, I reconnected with my creative side - and stumbled upon a YouTube tutorial about coding. That was the moment it all clicked! I'd found a way to combine creativity with technoligy. Today, I specialize in front-end development using HTML, CSS and JavaScript to build responsive, user-friendly websites. I design using Figma, Illustrator and Blender, and I've explored some backend basics to better understand full workflows and work more effectively in teams. I love experimenting with new tools and always try to bring a fresh skill into every project - wether it's for school or personal growth. I'm currently open to intership opportunities where I can grow, collaborate, and contribute to real-world digital experiences.

uiux.title: UI/ UX Design:
uiux.desc: I create user-friendly designs that are both easy to use and visually appealing.

frontend.title: Frontend Development
frontend.desc: I build responsive, fast-loading websites and apps using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

3d.title: 3D Design:
3d.desc: >I create 3D models and animations using Blender and bring ideas to life.

youthawear.description: YouthAWear was such a fun project! For our final project of the first schoolyear, we were tasked to create a digital product to raise awareness about sustainable fashion. I chose to design an online learning platform aimed at children aged 12 to 18. Through a series of interactive quiz-style games, users can learn about sustainability in fashion in a fun and engaging way. They can also create and customize their own avatars using a variety of sustainable clothing options, which they can buy and try on within the platform.

foodkiosk.description: Our final project in 3D Design focused on creating a food kiosk modeled after a street food of our choice. I designed mine around the Nigerian kitchen since I grew up with it. Set in a quiet park, the kiosk captures the simplicity and charm of eating a well-flavored meal on a warm summer evening with family and friends.

xdStickers.description: For the openingsweek of the new schoolyear at Thomas More, we were asked create something to put Digital Experience Design on the map! I came up with the fun idea of creating stickers resembling the course. Combining elements of both design and development, I designed stickers that reflect the essence of the curriculum.

zuiderbad.description:
Last schoolyear we've been given the opportunity to work with a real client! Our class got devided in 3 groups and each group was given a different client. My group worked with Zuiderbad, a horeca and event bureau in Mechelen.
They asked us to create an online map so people could navigate themselves better around the domain. My role within the project was to design the UI of the map and how it would look integrated on the existing website.

tunturi.description: For this project, I aimed to recreate the Tunturi home page using HTML and CSS...

figmaProjects.description: These are Figma projects I made between 2022 and now showcasing various design concepts and prototypes.

audromidaProject.description: Audromida is my very own portfolio website that you're currently viewing! Originally built for a school project, it has evolved into a showcase of my work and skills.

contact.title: Contact
contact.description: If you're interested in working together or have any questions, feel free to reach out!

popup.message: I really appreciate your interest in getting in touch! The email section of my website is still under construction. In the meantime, you can find my contact details in my CV. Thank you for your patience and understanding. ðŸ˜Š

post1.title: Hi there! Welcome to my blog
post1.preview: Why hello there and welcome to my blog! I'm very happy you decided to stop by and read my very first blog post here on Audromida. This blog is a place where you can follow my journey from a overly exited Digital Design 3rd year student to a professional webdesigner/developer. I'll write about the projects I'm working on, new things I learned, I'll even write about aswell as my intern ship that I'm doing next semester so look forward to that ðŸ‘€ ...
post1.content1: Why hello there and welcome to my blog! I'm very happy you decided to stop by and read my very first blog post here on Audromida.
post1.content2: Besides that, I'll also share personal stories and give some advice here and there.

post2.title: Why I started programming
post2.preview: So you want to know why I started programming huh? Well, it all started when I was born. ... Nah, just kidding! The real story takes place a few years later than that. I've always been a fairly creative person, partially because of my health issues that kept me indoors throughout my entire childhood. I had to look for ways to entertain myself that weren't just watching TV all day. Fortunately, I was a very imaginative kid, so I started drawing ...
post2.content: So you want to know why I started programming huh? Well, it all started when I was born. ... Nah, just kidding! The real story takes place a few years later than that. I've always been a fairly creative person, partially because of my health issues that kept me indoors throughout my entire childhood. I had to look for ways to entertain myself that weren't just watching TV all day. Fortunately, I was a very imaginative kid, so I started drawing and writing stories. Once I was a teenager people constantly kept saying I had to persue an artistic career because I was so talented. But I never really saw myself as an artist, more like a creative person. Drawing was something I did for fun, not for profit. So when the time came to choose a highschool study, I went for the safer option: Retail.
post2.content2: It was a mixure of creativity and it would land me a job once I graduated. And I did exactly that. I worked in couple different shops over the next few years, and thought I found my calling until ... Covid-19 hit. That whole period made me rethink my life, especially after I got laid off unexpectedly. I fell into a deep depression which took me a while to get out off honestly. Lockdown didn't help either. The fear of not knowing when our lives were going to return to normal if ever was truly mentally exhausting. The only thing I could do was try to keep myself busy and that meant spending alot of time watching shows, movies and YouTube videos. It was during one of those endless watching sessions that I stumbled upon a video about somebody coding their own website from scratch and my mind was blown!
post2.content3: I heard about coding before, but I never really thought about learning it myself. I felt too intimidated by the technical aspects of it all, thought I was too dumb to learn something like that. And yet, I kept watching more and more videos about it. Not only about people making websites, but also videogames, apps, animations, you name it. Seeing all the different things you could build, the endless creative possibilities. It intrigued me. I wanted to know more, better yet I wanted to learn it myself so once the world turned back to normal, and I had to find a new job, I decided to take a shot in the dark and went back to school instead to study webdesign. It was the best decision I've ever made.
post2.content4: I'll have to admit that I didn't land in webdesign right away. Basically when I had to look for a new job and told my adviser I wanted to go back to school to study computers I was aiming for graphic design. I thought that'd be the closest thing to art I could get but oh no. Turns out I had way more options than that. I was getting overwhelmed and time to enroll in a school was running out so one day my adviser just said: Here's a school closeby that offers webdesign, go to their info session and see if you like it. If you do, sign up. And so I did as I was told. And the rest is history. It was a short course but I learned so much from it. HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Photoshop, Illustrator and Figma. After I gratuated from there we were encouraged to keep learning so I took another shot in the dark and signed up for a more advanced course at college. Who would have thought that, me, going to college? Not me. But I am, and I'm loving every minute of it.
post2.content5: Programming opened up alot for me. Not only career wise, but also personally. Like I said before, I never saw myself as someone who'd go to college, let alone to go study programming. Both of those things seemed too farfetched for me to ever achieve. But apparently I am capable of way more than I give myself credit for. Learning how to code has boosted my self-confidence. It made me realize that I can learn new things, even if they seem difficult at first. And let me tell you, it was difficult at first. There were multiple times JavaScript made me cry because of how frustrating it was. I even had to retake the final exam because I failed it the first time. But I didn't give up. I kept practicing, redoing exercises, asked for help, looked up countless tutorials online until I finally figured it out and absolutely nailed that retake exam! That was the moment it all clicked for me. If I can achieve that, what else am I capable of? My programming journey is far from over, but I can't wait to see where it will continue to take me in the future ðŸ˜Š.

post3.title: Struggles of a webdesigner
post3.preview: When I tell someone I study Digital Experience Design, the most common response I get is: "Oh, so you work with computers?" and yeah, that's true, but it's way more than that. A big part of my study is learning how to design and code websites and apps which I absolutely love doing. However, one of the biggest struggles I face as a webdesigner is the creative block ...
post3.content:
When I tell someone I study Digital Experience Design, the most common response I get is: Oh, so you work with computers? and yeah, that's true, but it's way more than that. A big part of my study is learning how to design and code websites and apps which I absolutely love doing. However, one of the biggest struggles I face as a webdesigner is the creative block. There are days where I just can't come up with any new ideas for a project which is frustrating when you have deadlines to meet. It's especially frustrating when the assignment requires me to think out of the box and come up with something unique and innovative.
Luckily after 3 years in this course I've learned some techniques to overcome those creative blocks that work for me so I'm going to share them with you!
post3.content2: The first piece of advice I have is to simply take a break. Yes, it can be that easy sometimes. When you're stuck on a problem, stepping away from it for a little while and doing something else can help clear your mind and give you a fresh perspective. If you have other homework laying around, do that first. Or complete those chores you've been ignoring. Even changing your environment can help. Go for a walk outside, visit a friend, go walk your dog, anything that gets you out of your usual surroundings. When you return to the project later, you might find that the solution comes to you instantly.
post3.content3: Another technique that works for me is to look online for inspiration. Websites like Dribbble and Pinterest are great places to find design ideas. Scrolling through Instagram can also help to find new trends and styles. Just make sure you don't copy someone else's work, or start comparing yourself to others. Instead use it as a starting point to create something new and unique. Also, don't limit yourself to just online inspiration. Look at art, read a book, go into nature, listen to music, anything that sparks your creativity. You never know where your next idea will come from!
post3.quote: You never know where your next idea will come from!
post3.content4: Creative block sucks, but it's a normal part of the creative process. By taking breaks, seeking inspiration in new places, and practicing various brainstorming techniques, you can overcome those blocks and get back to creating amazing designs. So the next time you find yourself stuck, remember these tips and keep pushing forward!
post3.content5: Or just take a nap. Naps are great.
